ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A general overview of some current work/developments in IR.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength is that this course had a wonderful range of speakers, taken from pre-docs, post-docs and faculty. This meant the topics were diverse and fascinating. A slight problem for those who come from outside of the IR cohort is that the structure/requirements are not made clear at all, and there are several occasions when the timings are changed which may result in not being able to attend. This is a shame for what is otherwise a compelling series of discussions.

The International Relations workshop this semester had a good mix of speakers working on fascinating research topics. I thought the overlap of at least two sessions with ISS was particularly well thought out, and enjoyed both presentations given their security slant. I would like to see the workshop continue to aim for good balance of International Security, IO and IPE topics, and would also be curious to see more multi-method research design work being presented in IR (e.g., papers that use archival or interview-based research alongside statistical or experimental analysis).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Tentatively, yes. But if you come from outside the IR cohort, it can be a bit complicated in terms of knowing what your role is.
